results.title: Ladakh: little Tibet
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller, Chris McCullough, Stafford Garner, Ted Rayment and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journey into the Himalayas”.
Ladakh, known as Little Tibet, lies to the North East of Kashmir. Keith Adam finds that its barren moon-like landscape provides a stark contrast to the soft, green hills of Kashmir. The capital, Leh, has been for centuries an important regional trading centre, and remains as such today.

results.title: Pingu the magician
results.creator_credit: Otmar Gutman, Pingu Filmstudio and PINGU B V NL
results.brief_description: Pingu and his family and friends invite you join them in ten of their stories of fun and games. Stories on the tape include: ‘Pingu the magician’; ‘Pingu’s curling party’; ‘Pingu as an icicle player’; ‘Pingu’s outing’; ‘Pingu and the camera’; ‘Pingu’s parent’s have no time’; ‘Pingu and the packaging material’; ‘Pingu at the fairground’; ‘Pingu cannot lose’; and ‘Pingu and the disabled penguin’.

results.title: Ping pong
results.creator_credit: Marcel Carriere and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The National Film Board of Canada filmed the table tennis competition between teams of young Canadians and Chinese that took place in the People’s Republic of China in the summer of 1973, the first time in twenty-five years that such filming was made possible. Shown are highlights of play at the China-Canada Friendship Meet, as well as some of the sightseeing taken in by the young Canadians - a visit, for example, to the Great Wall of China. A film without commentary.

results.title: Pilgrimage of the devil worshippers
results.brief_description: A Kurdistan/Australian co-production. Yazidi villagers go on a pilgrimage annually to the holy shrine of Scheikh-Adi. This film follows the pilgrimage to its destination hidden deep in the Kurdistan valley. Filmed by Georges Drion. Commentary by Rob Antill.
results.description: A Kurdistan/Australian co-production. Yazidi villagers go on a pilgrimage annually to the holy shrine of Scheikh-Adi. This film follows the pilgrimage to its destination hidden deep in the Kurdistan valley. Filmed by Georges Drion. Commentary by Rob Antill.

results.title: Pile Ou Face = Heads or Tails
results.brief_description:
Edouard Morlaix’s wife dies after falling through a window. Inspector Baroni is convinced she was pushed by Morlaix who wanted to be free to run away with his mistress. Baroni starts harrassing Morlaix in the hope to have him break down and admit to the murder.

Credits: Producer, Georges Cravenne ; director, Robert Enrico ; writers, Robert Enrico, Michel Audiard, Marcel Jullian ; photography, Didier Tarot ; music, Lino Leonardi.
Cast: Philippe Noiret, Michel Serrault, Dorothee, Pierre Arditi, Andre Falcon, Fred Personne, Jean Desailly.

results.title: Pikangikum
results.creator_credit: John Gould, John Kemeny, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this film, made originally for theatrical use, the mood of the Pikangikum Indian Reserve in northern Ontario is evoked through snatches of dialogue and drawings by John Gould.

results.title: Pies
results.creator_credit: Sheldon Cohen, Caroline Leaf and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Based on a short story by Canadian author Wilma Riley, this animation film is about ethnic prejudice in all its blind viciousness. Mrs. Cherwak is Polish and owns a cow. Mrs. Meuser is a German with entrenched notions of cleanliness. She does not appreciate the cow’s inevitable by-product. The film describes their conflict and its curious resolution over coffee and mincemeat pie. While the author chose to write about the Germans and the Poles she grew up with on the outskirts of Regina, the situation she describes could apply anywhere in the world. (Award: New York.)
